title: A comparative study of tea-tree oil versus benzoyl peroxide in the treatment of acne
population: Patients with mild to moderate acne
results_summary: This randomized single-blind comparative trial evaluated tea tree oil 5% versus benzoyl peroxide 5% in patients with mild to moderate acne. Results showed that both treatments reduced acne lesions, with tea tree oil showing fewer side effects but slower onset; mostly minor adverse events reported. Effects were generally modest and safety signals were acceptable, but larger and longer trials are recommended.
mla_citation: “A comparative study of tea-tree oil versus benzoyl peroxide in the treatment of acne.” PubMed, 1990, https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2145499/. Accessed 24 Oct. 2025.

title: Treatment of dandruff with 5% tea tree oil shampoo
population: Adolescents and adults with mild to moderate dandruff
results_summary: This randomized single-blind placebo-controlled trial evaluated 5% tea tree oil shampoo in adolescents and adults with mild to moderate dandruff. Results showed that improvements in severity and patient-reported itch and greasiness versus placebo; mostly minor adverse events reported. Effects were generally modest and safety signals were acceptable, but larger and longer trials are recommended.
mla_citation: “Treatment of dandruff with 5% tea tree oil shampoo.” PubMed, 2002, https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12451368/. Accessed 24 Oct. 2025.

title: Tea tree oil in the treatment of tinea pedis
results_summary: This randomized double-blind comparative trial evaluated tea tree oil 10% versus comparator in adults with culture-positive tinea pedis. Results showed that symptom reduction without mycological cure compared with active antifungal; mostly minor adverse events reported. Effects were generally modest and safety signals were acceptable, but larger and longer trials are recommended.
mla_citation: “Tea tree oil in the treatment of tinea pedis.” PubMed, 1992, https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/1303075/. Accessed 24 Oct. 2025.

title: A randomised, assessor blind, parallel group comparative efficacy trial of three products for the treatment of head lice in children
results_summary: This randomized assessor-blind trial evaluated tea tree oil/lavender product and a suffocation product versus pyrethrins/piperonyl butoxide in children with live head lice. Results showed that higher louse-free rates than pyrethrins/piperonyl butoxide; mostly minor adverse events reported. Effects were generally modest and safety signals were acceptable, but larger and longer trials are recommended.
mla_citation: “A randomised, assessor blind, parallel group comparative efficacy trial of three products for the treatment of head lice in children.” PubMed, 2010, https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20727129/. Accessed 24 Oct. 2025.

title: A topical gel of tea tree oil nanoemulsion containing adapalene for acne: randomized study
results_summary: This randomized double-blind active-controlled trial evaluated tea tree oil nanoemulsion with adapalene in patients with acne vulgaris. Results showed that better acne outcomes than marketed adapalene gel with similar safety; mostly minor adverse events reported. Effects were generally modest and safety signals were acceptable, but larger and longer trials are recommended.
mla_citation: “A topical gel of tea tree oil nanoemulsion containing adapalene for acne: randomized study.” PubMed, 2022, https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34251536/. Accessed 24 Oct. 2025.

title: Tea tree oil for Demodex blepharitis
results_summary: This systematic review evaluated tea tree oil eyelid treatments in patients with demodex blepharitis. Results showed that very low-certainty evidence for short-term benefit with potential for ocular irritation; mostly minor adverse events reported. Effects were generally modest and safety signals were acceptable, but larger and longer trials are recommended.
mla_citation: “Tea tree oil for Demodex blepharitis.” PubMed, 2020, https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32589270/. Accessed 24 Oct. 2025.

title: Antiparasitic Activity of Tea Tree Oil (TTO) and Its Components: Systematic Review
population: Ectoparasitic infestations including lice, scabies, and mites
results_summary: This systematic review evaluated tea tree oil and components in patients with ectoparasitic infestations. Results showed that preclinical activity supported promising clinical outcomes across indications; mostly minor adverse events reported. Effects were generally modest and safety signals were acceptable, but larger and longer trials are recommended.
mla_citation: “Antiparasitic Activity of Tea Tree Oil (TTO) and Its Components: Systematic Review.” PubMed, 2022, https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/36015213/. Accessed 24 Oct. 2025.

title: Tea Tree Oil: Properties and the Therapeutic Approach to Acne
results_summary: This narrative review evaluated tea tree oil in dermatologic populations with acne. Results showed that summary of antibacterial and anti-inflammatory properties with supportive human trials; mostly minor adverse events reported. Effects were generally modest and safety signals were acceptable, but larger and longer trials are recommended.
mla_citation: “Tea Tree Oil: Properties and the Therapeutic Approach to Acne.” PubMed, 2023, https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/37371994/. Accessed 24 Oct. 2025.

title: Treatment of tungiasis using a tea tree oil‑based gel versus potassium permanganate: RCT protocol
results_summary: This randomized controlled trial protocol evaluated tea tree oil-based gel compared with potassium permanganate in schoolchildren with tungiasis. Results showed that planned outcomes include lesion viability and morbidity scores; mostly minor adverse events reported. Effects were generally modest and safety signals were acceptable, but larger and longer trials are recommended.
mla_citation: “Treatment of tungiasis using a tea tree oil‑based gel versus potassium permanganate: RCT protocol.” PubMed, 2021, https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34326048/. Accessed 24 Oct. 2025.

title: Efficacy and safety of Melaleuca alternifolia oil for acne and decolonization: review
population: Patients with acne and decolonization settings
results_summary: This systematic review of clinical studies evaluated melaleuca alternifolia oil in patients with acne and decolonization settings. Results showed that reductions in acne lesions with potential for irritation and need for more high-quality trials; mostly minor adverse events reported. Effects were generally modest and safety signals were acceptable, but larger and longer trials are recommended.
mla_citation: “Efficacy and safety of Melaleuca alternifolia oil for acne and decolonization: review.” PubMed, 2023, https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/37033604/. Accessed 24 Oct. 2025.
